title: The 'end of the era of the almighty central banker'
text:
This is “the end of the era of the almighty central banker,” agrees Citi’s chief European economist Arnaud Mares. It is “the end of the ‘central bank put’.”

Mares’s perspective is of a senior ECB insider now on the outside. The Frenchman spent five years as a special advisor to president Mario Draghi before joining Citi in 2017.

If rates below zero are making monetary policy counterproductive, why cut further below zero?

No surprise that Mares says September's decision was "entirely FX driven". The ECB knew the US Federal Reserve was about to cut and that this could push the euro higher at an awful time for the union. The ECB needed to show they could and would push rates lower in order to remain competitive in the global currency wars.

In other words, the 0.1 percentage point cut was designed to send a message to currency traders that rates could go lower.

Draghi knows interest rate policy is no longer effective in stimulating demand and has, in fact, become counterproductive. So what does he do? He also announces he will reinstate a €20 billion a month asset purchase program, with no specified end date.

Mares argues that the purpose of restarting QE - a controversial decision which Mares says he fully supports - is not to make financing costs as cheap as possible for businesses, which are reticent to invest in an era of negligible demand and high uncertainty.

For example, in the United Kingdom the uncertainty created by Brexit “will remain so large that effectively there is nothing the Bank of England can do to stimulate investment,” Mares says.

Instead, the restart of QE in Europe should be seen as paving the way for the next wave of stimulus: fiscal policy.

Central banks "need to take control of the cost of funding for governments and that is exactly what the ECB can do," Mares explains. By committing to relatively small but open-ended purchases of government paper, the ECB suppresses volatility in rates markets and creates the space for fiscal policy.

Effectively Draghi is saying to politicians, "Your funding will be virtually zero for the foreseeable future and whatever the circumstances - over to you".

That is why Mares believes this is “the end of the era of the almighty central banker”. They have largely done their dash and now the best they can do is provide the conditions for governments to borrow and spend.

"I think ECB will do nothing at all" from here, Mares says. Rates and asset purchases will remain where they are now for years to come.
description: A former special advisor to ECB boss Mario Draghi explains why monetary policy has lost traction and yet central bankers keep easing.
